Potentiometer

Using a potentiometer, we will be able to send a specified voltage to the ADC1 channel. Since each one of the ADC pins can only handle 1.8V Max as specified on the Circuitco wiki, we will use a voltage divider to set the maximum voltage right under 1.8V.

NOTE: In this example, we will use 2 10k ohm resistors in our voltage divider. Theoretically, the maximum voltage that the potentiometer will output is 1.65V, but it is better to be under 1.8V than be above, which can damage the processor. In the code, I have added a multiplier that will give you a 1 if the maximum voltage has been reached.

Voltage Divider: Vout = Vin(R1/R1+R2

Example 

var b = require('bonescript');
b.analogRead('P9_40', printAIN1);
var multiplier=1.1;

function printAIN1(x) {
    console.log('x.value = ' + x.value*multiplier);
    console.log('x.err = ' + x.err);
}




Build and execute instructions

  • Hook up the BeagleBone Black to the breadboard as shown in the diagram (above).
  • After clicking ‘run’, the ADC1 channel will give you a reading between 0-1, where 0 is 0V and 1 is the maximum input voltage (1.8V).
  • Adjust your potentiometer's knob and click run again. The lower the resistance, the higher voltage you will see.
  • Alter the code to look at inputs on other analog input pins. A schematic showing all available ADC channels are listed here.
